sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: * Corresponding author.

E-mail addresses: mohamed.salem@phrm.menofia.edu.eg (M.A. Salem), ahmed.zayed1@pharm.tanta.edu.eg (A. Zayed), Alseekh@mpimp-golm.mpg.de (S. Alseekh), Fernie@mpimp-golm.mpg.de (A.R. Fernie), giavalisco@age.mpg.de (P. Giavalisco).

The current research applied a non-targeted metabolomics approach to analyze different metabolites (e.g., phenolic compounds, lipids, organic acids, amino acids, and other primary metabolites) comprehensively in various crude fractions of fresh and dried ginger. It aimed to discriminate fresh ginger samples collected from different geographical regions based on metabolomics data. Moreover, the influence of the drying process on the metabolites profiles has also been investigated. Primary metabolites, especially amino acids, and intermediates were also investigated to trace the biosynthetic pathway of gingerols, while others as fatty acids and sugar monomers assessed the nutritive value of ginger.
2. Results
2.1. Chromatograms/spectra evaluation and metabolites annotation

Ginger samples collected from four different ginger-producing countries, i.e. , China , India , Pakistan , and Peru , in addition to lab-dried Peruvian samples were subjected to extraction and analysis ( Fig. 1 ). Representative total ion chromatograms of the analyzed ginger samples from both polar and non-polar fractions either in the positive and negative modes were depicted in Figure S1 and S 2 , respectively. The chromatograms obtained from the analyzed conditions were evaluated and aligned to obtain a data matrix of all tested samples, as presented in Figure S3.

A schematic diagram is presented in Fig. 2 showing the steps for confident compound identification taking [6]-gingerol as an example. The extracted ion chromatograms (EIC) of its protonated adduct was detected at m/z 295.191 [M+H] + with a retention time (RT) of 12.94 min. The predicted molecular formula for this adducts was C 17 H 27 O 4 . The ammoniated [M + NH 4 ] + as well as sodiated [M+Na] + adducts were also detected at the same RT showing m/z 312.217 and 317.173, respectively. A more intense and very prominent peak was detected at m/z 277.180 and RT of 12.94 min represented the loss of water from the protonated adduct [M-H 2 O + H] + . Alongside, a deprotonated adduct at m/z 293.175 [M-H] - was identified in the negative ionization mode eluted at the same RT ( Fig. 3A ). The predicted molecular formula for this adduct was C 17 H 25 O 4 . A deprotonation followed by addition of formic acid [M + FA-H] - at m/z 339.180 was also detected. Searching the molecular formula against common MS databases showed that the formula could be tentatively assigned to [6]-gingerol. Using the information from tandem MS, confirmation of the compound identification was based on detection of the characteristic fragment ions, as illustrated previously in Fig. 2 . The detected adducts and fragments of the same compound showed compatible positive correlation among the tested samples, indicating that they have the same precursor and adding more confidence in the identification as shown in Figure S4 .

Next to the use of the information about the detected adducts and fragmentation pattern in combination with co-elution, the elution profiles of compounds from the same class can be used for their collective identification. For instance, different gingerols showed a systematic retention time shift, according to their chain length on the RP column ( Fig. 3B ). Therefore, the separation was achieved according to their hydrophobic properties. Thus, [6]-gingerol that contains shorter carbon chain was eluted earlier (12.94 min) than [8]- and [10]-gingerol with longer chain length at 13.93 and 14.71 min, respectively. If the identified gingerols were plotted as scatter plots, with monoisotopic mass values on the x -axis and RT on the y-axis, other compounds from the same class can be predicted, as demonstrated in Fig. 3C . Using the same approach, all other metabolites were identified by their retention behavior, accurate mass measurements and MS/MS spectral data ( Table S1 ).

sec.title: 2.2. Metabolites discriminating the analyzed fresh ginger samples
sec.p: PCA analysis essentially allowed the separation of the analyzed samples based on their geographical closeness of the countries of origin ( Fig. 4A and Table S2). A closer look revealed that the three Asian samples were distinct from Peruvian sample of South America.

Phenylalanine and cinnamic acid are the precursors of [6]-gingerol. They showed similar metabolite pattern among the analyzed samples, as shown in Fig. 5 . These metabolites showed also the lowest abundance in Peruvian and Chinese samples, while the highest were in fresh Indian and Pakistani samples. In contrast, the pattern was reversed in case of [6]-gingerol, [6]-shogaol, hexahydrocurcumin, gingerenone A and gingerenone B. Other gingerols, i.e. , [8]- and [10]-gingerol as well as their methylated derivatives showed similar profiles, showing that the fresh Peruvian ginger was the richest in gingerols ( Fig. 5 and S 6 ). Interestingly, Chinese fresh ginger showed the highest abundance of gingerdiol and acetoxy derivatives ( Figure S6 ).

sec.title: 2.3. Metabolites discriminating the influence of drying ginger samples
sec.p:
Following the drying of Peruvian samples, PCA analysis essentially allowed the separation of the fresh and dried samples ( Fig. 7A ). Orthogonal projections to latent structures discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA) was applied to determine several markers that are distinct in dry samples ( Fig. 7B and C ). Overall, the top 25 metabolites with a VIP score greater than 1 were considered drying-specific informative metabolite markers ( Fig. 7D ). [6]-shogaol, which is derived from [6]-gingerol, was dramatically increased in dried samples. However, [6]-gingerdiol 5-
O - Î²
- D- glucopyranoside was not affected by drying process ( Fig. 8 ). A dramatic decrease in lipid classes and other primary metabolites, including xylose, riboflavin, and glutathione, was detected following drying process ( Figure S9 and S10). Similarly, the drying of ginger also led to a decrease in the starch content and the total amino acids pool (Figure S11).

sec.title: 2.4. Absolute quantification of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol
sec.p: Since [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol are considered the major bioactive compounds of ginger, different solvents were tested for their efficiency to recover them from fresh ginger samples. To determine their absolute concentration, UPLC/MS/MS analytical method was optimized. [6]-Gingerol and [6]-shogaol eluted at retention time of 3.3- and 4.4-min using RP-UPLC method, respectively. [6]-Gingerol and [6]- shogaol have molecular formulae of C 17 H 26 O 4 and C 17 H 24 O 3 with molar masses of 294.38 and 276.376 g /mol, respectively. By MS analysis, they showed better ionization in positive mode with the molecular ion peak at m / z 295.215 and 277.286, respectively, which were equivalent to protonated adduct (M+H) + , as shown in Table 1 . Additionally, by optimizing the multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) method, each compound showed three characteristic transitions. These fragments were used for qualitative identification, while the intense peaks at m / z 277.2 and 137.2, respectively, were used for absolute quantitative analysis (Figures S12 and S13). Absolute quantification of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol in fresh ginger samples was based on a standard calibration curve with a regression coefficient (R 2 ) of 0.999 within a linear range of 10 Î¼g/mL- 10 ng /mL and 1 Î¼g/mL- 0.1 ng /mL for [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol, respectively (Figure S14).

The result of this analysis showed that acetonitrile and methyl tert - butyl ether (MTBE) were the best solvents for extraction of [6]-gingerol, while isopropanol allowed the best extraction of [6]-shogaol, as shown in Fig. 9 . Since ginger is usually consumed as herbal tea or by adding ginger slices to fresh juices or water, we tested water as solvent for extraction. The results showed that using water also allowed the good extraction of both compounds, without noticeable differences between hot and cold extraction. Although the organic solvents allowed better extraction, the yield did not exceed 1.4-fold increase compared to water extraction. It is noteworthy to observe that the conversion of [6]- gingerol is not spontaneously induced during extraction with hot water.

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p: Ginger is usually available in different forms such as fresh ginger rhizomes, dried ginger spice or ginger herbal teas. In our study, ginger rhizome samples were collected from four different ginger-producing countries, i.e. , China , India , Pakistan , and Peru . The physical appearance of the collected ginger samples did not allow the discrimination according to the country of origin. Additionally, we subjected the fresh Peruvian ginger sample to laboratory drying which was analyzed to trace drying-induced metabolic changes.

Since the bioactivity and effectiveness of herbal extracts are determined by several constituents, a debate is being raised between using of the total crude extract and isolated single components which are responsible for bioactivity (
). Therefore, QC of the total extracts is required after optimization of extraction method to guarantee the presence of all constituents. This will allow analysis of several components simultaneously. Plant metabolomics has proven to be a powerful tool for herbal QC determining most of the herb phytoconstituents with high sensitivity and accuracy, especially when hyphenated spectrometric methods are used.

In addition, natural climate and geography have been proven to greatly influence plant metabolomes (
). Therefore, the ginger samples investigated in this study were collected from different localities to study the effect of geographical distribution on the metabolic content. The physical appearance of the collected ginger samples did not allow the discrimination according to the country of origin. Therefore, phytochemical investigation was required to determine the product quality and discriminate between different geographical origins ( China , India and Pakistan in Asia and Peru in Latin America). Results indicated the geographical origin affecting the primary and secondary metabolites abundances. For instance, the Peruvian ginger in addition to its high content of gingerols and paradols, showed the lowest content of free amino acids, glutathione, and starch either in fresh or lab-dried samples. By contrast, Chinese ginger was characterized by its high content of gingerdiols and their acetoxy derivatives. Furthermore, fresh Peruvian ginger was found to be the richest in most lipids adding a nutritive advantage over the Asian gingers.

Obviously, hot water extraction did not improve the conversion of gingerol and consequently increase in concentration of shogaol. This may be explained by the fact that the heat-induced dehydration of gingerol needs dryness and long exposure to high temperature or storage for a long period in warm conditions. The similar pattern of [6]- gingerdiol 5- Î² - D- glucopyranoside to [6]-gingerol either in fresh or dried samples confirmed that [6]-gingerdiol 5-Î²- D- glucopyranoside was not affected and resisted its conversion to other metabolites upon heat drying. The blockage of the dehydration site by the glucose molecule consequently inhibited the heat-induced dehydration step as occurred in [6]-gingerol. Jiang et al. have previously demonstrated that geographical origins of ginger did not affect plant genetics since all cultivated samples were genetically identical (
). Therefore, development of quality control based on chromatographic techniques is essential to guarantee robustness of the used analytical methods. Gingerols, including [6]-, [8]- and [10]-gingerol are responsible for ginger pungent taste. They were specially considered as potential markers for discrimination between the geographically different samples, in addition to the study the effect of drying process on the metabolic profile.

Application of non-targeted plant metabolomics provided comprehensive data regarding the phytochemical profiles of metabolites of ginger using MS-based metabolomics and chemometrics. It discriminated between ginger samples of different geographical origins and allowed assessment of the drying process. Additionally, the relation between primary metabolites, such as amino acids, i.e. , phenylalanine, and key intermediates of gingerols biosynthetic pathway emphasized the previously reported biosynthetic studies. A single compound is not enough for quality control and moreover the activity of the extract cannot be represented by single compound. Therefore, the applied metabolomic approach can be used in the field of quality control of herbal medicines providing more valuable information than singlecomponent analysis. Moreover, ginger showed richness in amino acids, sugars, organic acids and various lipids supported its use as a nutraceutical. From a nutritive perspective, fresh ginger is better than dried preparations, since it provides essential amino and fatty acids. However, dried ginger preparations are medicinally valuable, due to their higher contents of shogaols and organic phenolic acids. Furthermore, several non-gingerol related compounds were identified which may be promising as drug candidates or in revealing the secrets of the numerous bioactivities of ginger.

sec.title: 4.1. Reagents and chemicals
sec.p: Standards of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol were obtained from Sigma Aldrich (Steinheim, Germany ). LC-grade solvents were obtained from Biosolve Chemicals (Biosolve Chimie, Dieuze, France ). Standard solutions ( 1 mg /mL) of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol for HPLCâMS/MS analysis were prepared individually by dissolving each compound in 50% methanol and then were stored at 20 â¦ C until use.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant materials
sec.p:
Fresh ginger (
Zingiber officinale Roscoe
; Zingiberaceae ) rhizome samples, five replicates each, from China (Chinese ginger), India (Indian ginger), Peru (Peruvian ginger), Pakistan (Pakistani ginger) were purchased from BIO COMPANY GmbH ( Berlin , Germany ). All samples were randomized by origin and the fresh ginger samples were peeled with a knife carefully to remove the outer skin without damaging the inner layers. The peeled rhizomes were sliced into small pieces of almost the same thickness and length. The fresh Peruvian sample was chosen as a representative to study the effect of drying. It was cut into slices of 1 mm . Then, the slices were subjected to a tray drying in an oven (BINDER FD Heating ovens, Germany ) adjusted at 40 â¦ C for 1.5 days.

All samples were labeled and then kept frozen in liquid nitrogen until extraction. The initial moisture content of all samples was determined to remove the possible contribution of water content in subsequent determinations. All samples were weighed on an analytical balance (Sartorius, Germany ). They were then either oven-dried for 48 h at 80 â¦ C. After oven-drying, the samples were reweighed. The moisture content of all dried seaweed samples was calculated as follows: Moisture content (%) = [(weight before drying (g)) (weight after drying (g))] Ã 100 (weight before drying (g)).

sec.title: 4.3. Experimental design, sample extraction and analysis
sec.p:
Ginger samples collected from four different ginger-producing countries, i.e. , China , India , Pakistan , and Peru , were homogenized and the homogenized samples were subjected to extraction (
). Briefly, five replicates of 50 mg of each sample were placed in micro-centrifugation tube with pre-cooled (1 mL, 20 â¦ C) MTBE: methanol (MeOH) (3:1, v/v ), vortexed for 1 min followed by incubation on an orbital shaker (100 rpm) for 45 min at 4 â¦ C and then sonicated for 15 min. Additionally, a phase-separating step was conducted afterwards with 650 Î¼L H 2 O/MeOH (3:1, v/v ) followed again with a vortex step for 1 min and centrifugation at 20,000Ã g for 5 min at 4 â¦ C. The protocol resulted in the appearance of three different phases, including non-polar fraction represented by the MTBE upper layer, polar fraction in the middle MeOH/H 2 O layer, and a precipitated pellet in the lowest layer.

Afterwards, a fixed volume (500 Î¼L aliquots) of the upper MTBE layer was collected, dried for 3 h, and subjected to lipids analysis using reversed phase (RP) ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled with Fourier transform tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-C 8 -FT-MS/ MS). The samples were resuspended in 250 Î¼L acetonitrile:isopropanol (70:30) and 4 Î¼L was injected. In addition, fixed volumes (200 Î¼L and 400 Î¼L aliquots) of the middle MeOH/H 2 O layer were collected, dried for 12 h, and subjected to analysis using GC-TOF-MS and UPLC-C 18 -FT-MS/MS, respectively.

Furthermore, the whole protocol steps were similarly performed for blank samples, where the sample preparation, extraction, and analysis steps were repeated in the absence of plant materials, i.e. , empty extraction tubes. QC samples representing a pool made up of equal amounts of all investigated ginger specimen was also included for quality assessment purposes. QC were analyzed prior to sample acquisition and after every ten samples. They were used to confirm the stability and reproducibility of the analysis.

sec.title: 4.4.1. Non-polar fraction
sec.p: The upper MTBE layer was analyzed for lipid content by UPLC-C 8 - FT-MS/MS, where the Bridged Ethyl Hybrid (BEH) C 8 column (100 Ã 2.1 mm containing 1.7 Î¼m diameter particles, WatersÂ®, Manchester , UK ) was equipped with a Waters Acquity UPLC system (WatersÂ®, Manchester , UK ). The mobile phases were composed of buffer A consisted of aqueous 1% ( v/v ) 1 M ammonium acetate in 0.1% ( v/v ) acetic acid, while buffer B consisted of acetonitrile: isopropanol (7:3, v/v ) containing 1% 1 M ammonium acetate in 0.1% acetic acid. The UPLC system was programmed for metabolites separation by gradient elution with a flow rate adjusted at 400 Î¼L/min, The mobile phase composition varied by time to be 45% A for 1 min, 3 min gradient linear from 45% A to 35% A, 8 min linear from 25% A to 11% A, and then 3 min linear from 11% A to 1% A. Afterwards, the column was washed for 3 min with 1% A and then re-equilibrated by setting the mobile phase back to 45% A for 4 min.

sec.title: 4.4.2. Polar fraction
sec.p: UPLC-C 18 -FT-MS/MS consisted of RP-High Strength Silica (HSS) T3 C 18 column (100 Ã 2.1 mm containing 1.7 Î¼m diameter particles, WatersÂ®), combined with Waters Acquity UPLC system (WatersÂ®, Manchester , UK ) and a mobile phase flow rate at 400 Î¼L/min. The mobile phases of the chromatographic separation were aqueous 0.1% formic acid (buffer A) and methanol containing 0.1% formic acid (buffer B). Linear gradient elution was also applied using 99% A for 1 min, from 99% A to 65% A till 13 min, then 65% A to 30% A till 14.5 min, 30% A to 1% A till 15.5 min, hold at 1% An until the 17 min, and finally to 17.5 min a linear gradient from 1% A to 99% A. The column was re-equilibrated by 99% A for 2.5 min. The UPLC system was coupled with mass spectrometer (MS) worked in positive and negative ionization mode using a heated electrospray ionization (HESI) source together with an Exactive, Orbitrap-type, MS (Exactive, Thermo-FisherÂ®, Bremen , Germany ).

The instrumentation and chromatographic parameters of GC-TOF-MS were performed as previously described (
). Briefly, aliquots of the polar phase (0.2 mL) were dried down before they were re-suspended in 40 Î¼L of methoxyamine-hydrochloride/pyridine solution followed by heating at 37 â¦ C for 90 min. The samples were further derivatized with 90 Î¼L of N -methyl- N -trimethylsilyltrifloracetamide (MSTFA) for 30 min at 37 â¦ C. One Î¼L of the derivatized sample mixture was injected onto the GC-column and measured.

4.6. Data analysis
sec.p: The chromatograms obtained from the analyzed samples were evaluated and aligned to obtain a data matrix of all tested samples. In addition, metabolite features were grouped according to accurate mass difference, retention time, and correlation between metabolite features across all samples. The data analysis obtained from either UPLC-C 8 -FT-MS/MS or UPLC-C 18 -FT-MS/MS was performed using the Progenesis QI software package (Progenesis QI Version 2.2, Nonlinear Dynamics, Newcastle , UK ). The resulted UPLC or GC matrices were imported into Microsoft Excel (Excel, 2010; Microsoft, Redmond, USA ). Only compounds with at least five-fold higher intensity in comparison to the blank peaks were further considered for analysis. Compounds that showed missing values in more than two of the five biological replicates were excluded. Metabolite data obtained were normalized by weight, followed by using internal standard normalization. All statistical analyses were performed using the algorithms embedded within Microsoft excel. Bar graphs were plotted using either Excel or Sigma Plot 12.5 (http://www.sigmaplot.co.uk).

sec.title: 4.7. Quantitative determination of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol
sec.p: To evaluate the absolute [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol concentrations in fresh ginger samples, different extraction solvents were applied followed by UPLC/MS/MS analysis. Aliquots ( 50 mg each) of the tested samples were extracted with 1 mL of either; water, 25% MeOH, 50% MeOH, 75% MeOH, 100% MeOH, acetonitrile, ethyl acetate, MTBE, or isopropanol. The hot water extraction was performed by adding the hot water (80 â¦ C) to ginger samples and the extraction was kept at 80 â¦ C for 30 min. For extraction, the samples were vortexed quickly, incubated on an orbital shaker for 30 min, sonicated for 10 min and finally centrifuged at 10,000Ã g for 10 min. Standard dilution series of [6]-gingerol and [6]- shogaol were prepared in 50% MeOH/H 2 O in the range of 0â10 Î¼g/mL for calibration curve construction.

The samples and standards were separated by a RP-UPLC system ( Waters Acquity UPLC system, Waters Â®, Manchester , UK). A high strength silica (HSS) T3 column ( 100 mm Ã 2.1 mm containing 1.8 Î¼m diameter particles, Waters Â®, Manchester , UK ) fitted with 2.1 Ã 5 mm guard column (ACQUITY UPLC HSS T3 VanGuard Pre-column , 100 Ã , 1.8 Î¼m, Waters Â®, Manchester , UK) was used. The gradient parameters for RP-UPLC were as follows: 80% eluent A (aqueous 0.1% formic acid) for 6.5 min, 45% B (0.1% formic acid in methanol) from 6.5 to 7 min; 10% A from 7 to 7.1 min, held at 0% A from 7.1 to 8.1 min, returned back to initial the conditions by 8.1 min. Finally , the column was re-equilibrated and conditioned to 80% A from 8.1 to 10 min. The column temperature was set at 40 â¦ C, the flow rate was 0.4 Î¼L/min, the autosampler temperature was set at 10 â¦ C, and the injection volume was 7.5 Î¼L. Moreover , the MS/MS analysis following the UPLC step was achieved using a quadrupole/ linear ion trap (QLIT) mass analyzer (4000 QTRAP, AB Sciex Germany GmbH, Darmstadt , Germany ) in multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) scan type equipped with an electrospray ionization source ( Turbo V â¢ Ion Source , AB Sciex ). The operating parameters for MS/MS analysis were as follows: ion polarity; positive, ion source; Turbo spray, capillary ion spray voltage; 5.5 kV, probe tip position; 5 mm , source temperature; 500 â¦ C, carrier gas; nitrogen, curtain gas; 25 psi, nebulizing gas (GS1) and focusing gas (GS2); 40 psi, interface heater. Furthermore , Analyst software (version 1.6.2, AB Sciex ) was used for instrument control next to data acquisition, processing, and analysis (
, 2020b).
